adventLectionary.title: The Messiah will be born of a virgin
adventLectionary.segment: Isaiah is prophesying to King Ahaz of Judah who reigned from 732 to 716 bc. The southern kingdom of Judah is being threatened by the alliance of two enemies: the northern kingdom of Israel and Syria. This frightening scenario gives Isaiah an opportunity to speak encouraging words of hope to calm a desperate king Ahaz. He need not fear because Immanuel God would be with them.
adventLectionary.html:
Isa 71When Ahaz, son of Jotham and grandson of Uzziah, was king of Judah, King Rezin of Syria* and Pekah son of Remaliah, the king of Israel, set out to attack Jerusalem. However, they were unable to carry out their plan.

2The news had come to the royal court of Judah:

A MESSENGER

Syria is allied with Israel* against us!

So the hearts of the king and his people trembled with fear, like trees shaking in a storm.

3Then the Lord said to Isaiah,

GOD

Take your son Shear-jashub* and go out to meet King Ahaz. You will find him at the end of the aqueduct that feeds water into the upper pool, near the road leading to the field where cloth is washed.* ...

10Later, the Lord sent this message to King Ahaz:

god

11Ask the Lord your God for a sign of confirmation, Ahaz. Make it as difficult as you want—as high as heaven or as deep as the place of the dead.*

12But the king refused.

AHAZ OF JUDAH

No,

he said,

AHAZ OF JUDAH

I will not test the Lord like that.

13Then Isaiah said,

ISAIAH

Listen well, you royal family of David! Isn’t it enough to exhaust human patience? Must you exhaust the patience of my God as well? 14All right then, the Lord himself will give you the sign. Look! The virgin* will conceive a child! She will give birth to a son and will call him Immanuel (which means ‘God is with us’)...

Mat 118This is how Jesus the Messiah was born. His mother, Mary, was engaged to be married to Joseph. But before the marriage took place, while she was still a virgin, she became pregnant through the power of the Holy Spirit. 19Joseph, to whom she was engaged, was a righteous man and did not want to disgrace her publicly, so he decided to break the engagement* quietly.

20As he considered this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream.

AN ANGEL

Joseph, son of David,

the angel said,

AN ANGEL

do not be afraid to take Mary as your wife. For the child within her was conceived by the Holy Spirit. 21And she will have a son, and you are to name him Jesus,* for he will save his people from their sins.

22All of this occurred to fulfill the Lord’s message through his prophet:

23“Look! The virgin will conceive a child!
She will give birth to a son,
and they will call him Immanuel,*
which means ‘God is with us.’”

24When Joseph woke up, he did as the angel of the Lord commanded and took Mary as his wife. 25But he did not have sexual relations with her until her son was born. And Joseph named him Jesus.

Isa 7:1 Hebrew Aram; also in 7:2, 4, 5, 8.
Isa 7:2 Hebrew Ephraim, referring to the northern kingdom of Israel; also in 7:5, 8, 9, 17.
Isa 7:3a Shear-jashub means “A remnant will return.”
Isa 7:3b Or bleached.
Isa 7:11 Hebrew as deep as Sheol.
Isa 7:14 Or young woman.
Mat 1:19 Greek to divorce her.
Mat 1:21 Jesus means “The Lord saves.”
Mat 1:23 Isa 7:14; 8:8, 10 (Greek version).
adventLectionary.Questions:
• Matthew says that Jesus' birth fulfills Isaiah's message about Immanuel. Consider situations in your life in which you - like Ahaz - may have felt overwhelmed and fearful. Has there been a time in your life in which it looked like all hope was lost? How could God's Immanuel presence make a difference in such a time?
  • An angel tells Joseph to name this miraculous child “Jesus” which means “the Lord saves” in Hebrew. He goes on to explain that Jesus comes to save us "from" our sins. The Greek preposition translated “from” is very visual. It's as if you walked out of a house and kept walking further and further away “from” the house. In the same way Jesus' salvation is intended to help distance us more and more from sin and its consequences. How can you let Jesus help you distance yourself more and more from sin during this Advent season?"
  • For further reflection, you may want to download a PDF of Brother Lawrence's famous book, Practicing the Presence of God
